citation.title: Mapping the future expansion of Arctic open water

news.title: Less ice, more water in Arctic Ocean by 2050s
news.summary: By the 2050s, parts of the Arctic Ocean once covered by sea ice much of the year will see at least 60 days a year of open water, according to a new modeling study led by researchers at the University of Colorado Boulder.

news.title: An Arctic Forecast
news.summary: In the early months of 1846, a hundred and twenty-six sailors and officers, commanded by Captain John Franklin of the Royal British Navy, sailed south from their winter harbor on Beechey Island, in the Canadian Arctic.

news.title: Less ice, more water in Arctic Ocean by 2050s
news.summary: Home Earth Earth Sciences November 2, 2015 November 2, 2015 By the 2050s, parts of the Arctic Ocean once covered by sea ice much of the year will see at least 60 days a year of open water, according to a new modeling study led by researchers at the…

news.title: How the Planet Will Change Without Arctic Sea Ice
news.summary: By midcentury, the Arctic coastline and most of the Arctic Ocean will be devoid of sea ice for an additional 60 days each year, with some regions seeing closer to 100 days more of open water, according to a study released this week in the journal…

news.title: Menos hielo en el Océano Ártico para la década de 2050 — Noticias de la Ciencia y la Tecnología (Amazings®  / NCYT®)
news.summary: Hacia la década del 2050, partes del Océano Ártico que antaño estaban cubiertas por hielo marino casi todo el año, contarán con no menos de 60 días anuales de aguas abiertas (sin hielo), según un nuevo estudio de modelado.

author.name: NCYT - Noticias de la Ciencia y la Technologia

news.title: Less ice, more water in Arctic Ocean by 2050s, new CU-Boulder study finds
news.summary: By the 2050s, parts of the Arctic Ocean once covered by sea ice much of the year will see at least 60 days a year of open water, according to a new modeling study led by researchers at the University of Colorado Boulder.

news.title: Arctic melt boosts northern trade routes, hurts Suez
news.summary: The melting ice caps will not only impact our coastlines, but may radically alter international trade, a new study finds.
